head.title: Candidates, Rise to the Global Challenge

hedline.hl1: Candidates, Rise to the Global Challenge

abstract.p: Steven C Mendelsohn letter on Thomas L Friedman's May 12 article urges presidential candidates to offer vision of future that reflects understanding of sweeping technological changes; drawing

block.p: In ''The Parallel Universe'' (column, May 12), Thomas L. Friedman paints a frightening picture of a near future very different from our comfortable, familiar present. He adds that the current presidential candidates cannot be faulted for ignoring these issues in their hunger for office.

In ''The Parallel Universe'' (column, May 12), Thomas L. Friedman paints a frightening picture of a near future very different from our comfortable, familiar present. He adds that the current presidential candidates cannot be faulted for ignoring these issues in their hunger for office.

Mr. Friedman, like so many of us, is asking far too little from the next leader of the free world. We comfort ourselves with this disappointing pair of candidates by concluding that in times of relative peace and prosperity, there's not much damage they can do.

We should feel fully justified in expecting something more thoughtful from our candidates than a pre-packaged position on Elian or the Stars and Bars. We should demand from each a vision of the future that reflects an understanding of the sweeping changes our technology will usher in.
STEVEN C. MENDELSOHN Montclair, N.J., May 12, 2000
